ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Question 4: The workload for this course was heavy, and it was all loaded at the end of the semester. It would have been helpful to have started group projects earlier on in the semester.In addition, a syllabus with all assignments and due dates would have been very helpful. Most of the assignments in this class were surprises and we only had 1 week's notice to complete them; it made planning workloads around other courses and schedule very difficult.
4. The workload towards the end of the semester was far too heavy. A Group paper, presentation, and final exam all in one week is overwhelming. Also, due dates of Christmas Eve discourage efficiency.
More field trips! Field trips are very helpful, often more so than lecture in communicating river dynamics and processes

This was an interesting topic of instruction. However, it was a lecture based course and I did not find it particularly engaging. I would have liked if the professor provided more case studies for analysis and class discussion after learning the basics.Also, towards the end of the course we worked on a field project. I would have liked if we could have started a little earlier. This would have allowed us to put more time into the project and learn more.
field trips and group project
Being out in the field with Jim. The final project allowed hands on experience to learn more about river management.
The instructor was thorough and dedicated.
The first field trip was great.
The fields were the most beneficial part of this class. They really helped to solidify the concepts and gave me a better understanding of how river processes are evaluated in the field.
Field trips!!!
Field trips were helpful.

The professor has a wealth of knowledge about river restoration and is an excellent source for any questions you may have on the topic. He is also connected to many people in the field and can provide practical advice on topics of interest.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: too much busy work/book report-type assignments
Need a complete syllabus with assignments listed on them!

The syllabus needs to provide more detail regarding the semester's workload so that students can budget their time accordingly. Also, having a group paper and presentation, in addition to a take home final was too heavy of a work load for the end of the semester.

Too often a long essay was dropped on us at the last minute. Given that we all have multiple commitments, it is very difficult to plan when we have no idea what is going to be assigned. Ideally, homework is assigned in advance to allow for proper planning.

Basically the course mainly deals with the identification of various terms and characteristics. After having this course I may have good knowledge of fish passage but may not feel much competent about the the other technical issues which are supposed to be addressed quite often.
Too much river classification. That should have been one class and that's it. Much too much Rosgen.

It would have been very helpful if the final projects were distributed to the class at the beginning of the semester rather than at the end of the semester. The project was the most beneficial part of the class, so it would have been helpful to have some more time to focus on the content of the project.
We could cover more material in class to add to the technical skills.It would be useful if examples were extended outside US as well.
Final projects should be assigned a little earlier. We had to do: 1) class presentations on a paper, 2) final projects, and 3) final exams within a short space of time.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: terrific
Excellent
Both were very available and willing to help. Chris was great.
It was always pleasing to interact with him and he always helped a lot.
The instructor was extremely helpful and always made himself available.The TA was also very helpful and always offered to help us at anytime throughout the semester.
excellent
He was always available and helpful.

The instructor was very helpful. He offered additional training sessions for online programs outside of class. The TA was also very helpful. He always made himself available to students and did a good job of facilitating communication between students and the professor.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: great skills course. built upon theoretical knowledge gained in hydrology
As a student focused on water resource management, there are few classes that fit better into my overall program than this one did. I wish there were more.
As a professional one has to face all the faces of the river in the field so it a great course and I personally feel need some modification in the course content.
I have an interest in rivers and fish.

This course offered valuable knowledge about river processes and different restoration considerations. I am interested in water resources management, so it helped to bolster my knowledge of fluvial geomorphology.
Strengthening understanding of river processess - physical and ecological
I am interested in water resources management and this course was helpful.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: to gain more skills and familiarity related to the course concepts
I'm focused on water resource management and so is this class.
I wanted to upgrade my knowledge
Formal training in river processes.
I wanted to supplement my knowledge of river processes from a scientific perspective. I also wanted to learn about some of the restoration strategies that are currently being used by practitioners.
Interest
I was interested in getting hands-on experience in river restoration. The finalproject for the course provided an excellent opportunity to do so.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes
Exceeded them.
Not Exactly
Could have been better. The course seemed to be repetitive.

This course did live up to my expectations, although I already had a lot of this knowledge from previous coursework in my undergraduate studies. I was hoping the content would be a little more in-depth.
Yes
To a certain degree, yes. It would have been helpful if there were more opportunities to analyze case studies.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
Yes! Learned a lot about river processes, and am now much more interested in the subject within my general field of water resource management.
Yes, I only wish there was an additional class offered in spring.
I was able to learn about some of the restoration strategies, which was helpful. Also, the project allowed me to apply some of the knowledge learned in class to a real-world scenario.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: good learning opportunity. no real disadvantages
Great opportunity working together in the field and learning from each other on the project.
It is worth learning
Makes projects more enjoyable.

The main advantage of group work was that I was able to share my ideas with my group members and vice versa. Through this collaboration process, we were able to develop strong, well thought out recommendations.I cannot think of any disadvantages of the group work for this course.
One team member did not contribute at all. And this was very frustrating.
All the teammates did not contribute equally.
Advantage: It was an opportunity to discuss different management options with a group and get feedback on my written work.Disadvantage: One student failed to contribute to the project.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Start your group project right when they are assigned to avoid having too much work to do at the very end of the semester.
Jim knows a lot about rivers!

If you have a background in river processes and restoration, I would not recommend taking this class. The course material begins with the basics, so we do not have a chance to go in-depth on a lot of the material.
Start your project work early.
Identify a project you are interested in. If you decide to work in a group, ensure that your group members are equally excited about contributing to the project.
